origin_history: Part of mixed Herb Planter seeded on Nov 12, 2025.
Planted in black planter 23.5" × 7.85" × 6" center front.
Shares planter with Thai Basil, Cilantro, Oregano, and Thyme.
whats_been_logged: The planting began with very dry, alkaline soil that was rehydrated and corrected with lime. Parsley's naturally slow germination meant a longer wait before seeing sprouts compared to neighboring herbs. First seedlings emerged on Nov 21 with healthy upright cotyledons. Seedling expansion has continued steadily with many new cotyledons now visible across the sowing band as soil moisture and pH conditions stabilized.
current_state: Seeds in place; parsley's natural slow-germination behavior means a longer wait before seeing sprouts.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley shows vigorous, upright early true leaf growth with excellent hydration following last night's rain. Leaf color is uniformly bright and healthy across the stand, and the canopy appears denser and more layered than the previous day. Soil surface is evenly moist without puddling, and no signs of pest damage or stress are visible.
journal.actions: No watering required. Do not fertilize or apply lime today as soil and pH conditions are ideal.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow mid-morning as sunny conditions may promote steady dry-down. Continue monitoring canopy expansion and anticipate early massing stage development over the next few days.

photos.caption: Parsley on 12/10 showing lush, hydrated foliage with uniform color and upright posture following recent rainfall.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley shows lush, upright true leaf growth with consistent healthy color across the entire planting band. Leaves are expanding rapidly and show no stress, burn, or pest activity. Soil structure appears improved after filling the probe hole, lightly fluffing the surface, and adding a small amount of Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix, resulting in a more even, aerated top layer. Moisture is low this morning, though the canopy still appears hydrated and stable.
journal.actions: Hold watering for now and allow forecasted storms to provide natural rehydration. Do not apply fertilizer or lime today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning after expected rainfall. Monitor pH for natural settling back toward the mid-6 range as soil equilibrates. Continue watching for rapid true leaf expansion.
follow_up: [4:38 PM] Sprayed Captain Jack’s DeadBug lightly across the entire window box at soil level to eliminate or expose any cutworms that may have dropped into the soil and to prevent potential nighttime stem damage to cilantro and the other herbs.

photos.caption: Parsley on 12/09 showing vigorous true leaf expansion and improved soil structure after light surface adjustments.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley shows vigorous early true leaf growth with bright, uniform color and upright posture across the planting band. The soil is heavily saturated from recent moisture, but seedlings appear unaffected with no signs of wilt, discoloration, or fungal stress. The pH reading is slightly acidic for parsley but remains within a tolerable range while seedlings continue healthy expansion.
journal.actions: Do not water at this time due to high soil moisture. Avoid applying lime or fertilizer today while the soil remains saturated.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow afternoon as storms clear. Allow natural dry-down to bring moisture into the 40–60 range before applying a small dolomite lime correction to stabilize pH. Monitor new growth for any paling that may indicate advancing acidity effects.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 12/08 showing upright, vigorous true leaf development across the sowing band despite very wet soil conditions.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 86°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley shows vigorous early growth with bright green, well-hydrated true leaves. The canopy is dense and upright with no signs of heat stress, wilt, pests, or nutrient imbalance. Initial probe difficulty was due to overly dry surface soil, but final reading reflects stable mid-range moisture and excellent overall soil conditions.
journal.actions: No watering needed at this time. Avoid fertilizing while early true leaves continue developing.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow afternoon following expected showers. Continue monitoring canopy expansion and plan to introduce a very light fertilization once true leaf mass significantly increases.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 12/07 showing dense, vibrant true leaf growth with upright structure and healthy color.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings show clear development of their first true leaves with healthy green coloration and upright growth. The canopy is fuller and more layered than previous days, and soil moisture remains in a safe mid-range with no signs of stress from wind gusts.
journal.actions: No watering or amendments needed at this time.
journal.next_steps: Monitor wind exposure through the afternoon and continue watching for progression of true leaves. Avoid fertilizing until true leaves strengthen.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User provided a list of available garden products for future reference.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 12/02 showing first true leaves emerging across a dense, healthy canopy.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 66°F overnight. Partly cloudy conditions expected around 1 PM.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain vigorous with upright cotyledons and consistent color across the planting band. Soil surface is even and well supported after refilling and leveling the probe hole, with no signs of dryness or stress.
journal.actions: No additional watering was needed following the morning irrigation at 9:40 AM.
journal.next_steps: Continue maintaining even soil surface and monitor moisture as conditions shift toward partly cloudy skies.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted watering at 9:40 AM and soil leveling after probe removal.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/29 displaying strong cotyledon growth and stable soil structure after morning watering.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72°F dropping to 57°F overnight. Clear conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings show vigorous, upright cotyledon growth with excellent color and density across the sowing band. Moisture is elevated but still within a safe range and seedlings remain well supported by the leveled soil surface.
journal.actions: No watering needed due to high moisture and expected natural drying later today.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture through the evening and continue watching for the first true leaves to emerge.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/28 showing dense, upright cotyledons with healthy color and well-supported soil structure.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping down to 65°F overnight. Rainy conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings remain strong and upright with dense, even cotyledon coverage across the sowing band. Color and structure are healthy with no signs of stress or disease, and soil adjustments have improved support around developing roots.
journal.actions: No watering needed due to sufficient moisture and expected evening rain.
journal.next_steps: Monitor after rainfall to ensure soil does not become overly compacted or waterlogged. Continue watching for the first true leaves.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted probe width was creating soil pockets and has been leveling and refilling soil around seedlings.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/27 showing dense and vigorous cotyledon growth with improved soil leveling around the roots.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping down to 67°F overnight. Thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings continue to expand uniformly with vigorous upright cotyledons. No signs of stress, disease, or nutrient imbalance. Moisture is moderate and safe ahead of expected thunderstorms.
journal.actions: No watering needed given current moisture levels and approaching rain.
journal.next_steps: Monitor after storms to ensure soil does not become overly compacted. Continue watching for the first true leaves.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/26 showing dense, healthy cotyledon growth across the sowing band.

journal.conditions: Sunny all day with a high of 84°F dropping down to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings showed strong upright growth with increasing density throughout the sowing band. No signs of water stress and no visual issues following the afternoon watering.
journal.actions: No additional watering needed after the 2:33 PM irrigation.
journal.next_steps: Maintain steady surface moisture and continue monitoring for any signs of heat or dryness under full sun.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/25 showing expanded healthy cotyledons following afternoon watering.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping down to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings have expanded into a dense, healthy stand across the sowing band. All cotyledons are upright, narrow, and correctly shaped with no discoloration or stress symptoms. Soil moisture has recovered from earlier dryness, and pH has moved upward into a safer range for continued early growth.
journal.actions: No additional watering or adjustments needed at the time of the reading.
journal.next_steps: Maintain steady surface moisture and monitor for the first true leaves. No fertilizer until true leaves fully form.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted the soil was extremely dry this morning before watering; current readings were taken roughly 60 minutes after rehydration.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings on 11/24 showing vigorous, uniform cotyledon growth across the sowing band.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley seedlings have expanded significantly since initial emergence, with many new cotyledons now visible across the sowing band. Seedlings appear healthy, upright, and bright green with correct parsley cotyledon shape. Soil surface shows heavy sun exposure and pronounced drying, consistent with probe moisture being critically low. No signs of stress yet, but watering was needed promptly.
journal.actions: Apply immediate light watering to restore moisture for newly emerged seedlings. No fertilizer at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Maintain consistent light surface moisture to support early seedling growth. Avoid disturbing the area. Monitor pH trend as lime continues to buffer acidity. Watch for first true leaves over the next 7-10 days.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Noted many new sprouts expanding normally after emergence.
follow_up: [2:11 PM] Applied light shower to rehydrate the parsley zone.

photos.caption: Parsley seedlings showing expanded emergence with many healthy cotyledons across the sowing band.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley sprouts confirmed to be the same seedlings first observed on 11/21. Seedlings appear healthy with upright cotyledons. Soil surface showed reduced moisture compared to the day before, consistent with the probe reading.
journal.actions: Apply light watering to restore top-inch moisture for new sprouts.
journal.next_steps: Continue light, even watering to keep the upper layer moist. Avoid fertilizer until true leaves develop. Monitor pH for gradual improvement as lime continues to buffer acidity.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Clarified that sprouts were present the day before; emergence date confirmed as 11/21.
follow_up: [11:37 AM] Applied watering to the parsley zone.

photos.caption: Parsley cotyledons showing same seedlings as 11/21, confirming emergence timing.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley section remains unsprouted, which is still normal at only nine days after sowing. Soil shows moderate moisture and slight surface disturbance, but no signs of algae, mold, or compaction issues. Nearby thyme sprouts are visible, but no parsley cotyledons yet.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer needed. Allow lime application from earlier this week to continue adjusting soil pH. Avoid disturbing the parsley zone to protect germinating seeds.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture daily and keep the top layer lightly moist but not wet. Expect the earliest parsley sprouts in the next 5-14 days. Recheck pH later in the week to confirm upward trend.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Noted possible sprouts, which were clarified to be thyme rather than parsley. Sprout absence is still fully normal for parsley's slow germination timeline.

photos.caption: Parsley zone showing moist, uneven surface with no parsley sprouts yet and thyme seedlings visible on the right side.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley section remains sprout-free, which is still normal for its slow germination. Soil is warm and moderately moist with a slightly acidic pH and visible thyme sprouts just beyond the parsley boundary.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer needed at this time. Leave the soil undisturbed so parsley seeds can continue their slow germination process.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring over the next 7-14 days for first parsley sprouts. Maintain even moisture without overwatering, especially during hot afternoons.

photos.caption: Parsley zone soil showing moist, warm surface with no visible parsley sprouts yet.

journal.conditions: Clear with full sun and a temperature of 69.4°F.
journal.observations: No parsley sprouts yet, which is normal for its delayed germination. Soil moisture is moderate and pH is improving toward ideal range.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Maintain full sun exposure.
journal.next_steps: Continue waiting 10-21 days for sprout development as parsley germinates slowly.
follow_up: [3:07 PM] Applied lime across herb box. Soil was very dry two knuckles down, so light surface watering was provided to re-moisten the upper layer without washing lime deeper.

photos.caption: Parsley soil surface.
Herb box after lime application on the afternoon of 11/19.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley section remains unsprouted, which is normal for slow parsley germination. Soil moisture is slightly higher but still healthy.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Avoid compacting the soil surface.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring; parsley may not show sprouts for another week or more.

photos.caption: Parsley zone with moist, settled soil and no sprouts yet.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: Parsley section remains unsprouted as expected. Soil is evenly moist with pH slightly low across the planter.
journal.actions: Include parsley area in the light lime top-dress applied to the planter.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring moisture. Parsley germination is expected later than the other herbs.

photos.caption: Parsley area showing moist soil but no sprouts.

journal.conditions: Clear with morning shade transitioning to sun and a temperature of 67°F.
journal.observations: Soil is still on the dry side but improving compared to the previous day. No sprouts visible in this section yet as seeds continue early water uptake.
journal.actions: Apply gentle watering to keep the top layer evenly moist. No fertilizer needed at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture the next morning and continue watching for first signs of germination over the coming days.

photos.caption: Herb planter surface showing moistening soil and no sprouts yet.

journal.conditions: Clear with full sun and a temperature of 65°F.
journal.observations: Initial reading shows very dry soil and alkaline pH across the planter. No seedlings present; seeds are likely just beginning water uptake after sowing.
journal.actions: Apply thorough soaking to correct dryness, taking care not to displace seeds. No fertilizer at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Expect slow pH change over the coming days. Recheck moisture and pH with follow-up readings as germination window begins.

photos.caption: First-day view of the herb planter with dry soil before rehydration.
